title: Color-code change types in changes column
description: Add color coding to individual change types in the changes column (M for modified, D for deleted, A for added, ?? for untracked, etc.) to improve visual scanning and identification. Each change type should have a distinct color.

comments.author: jmocito
comments.text:
Proposed color scheme for change types:

- M (Modified) → Yellow - indicates changed files
- D (Deleted) → Red - indicates removed files  
- A (Added) → Green - indicates new staged files
- ?? (Untracked) → Cyan - indicates new untracked files
- R (Renamed) → Magenta - indicates renamed files
- C (Copied) → Blue - indicates copied files

Example display: "M:3 D:1 ??:2" would render with each type in its designated color.

Implementation approach:
1. Parse the change_summary string (currently formats like "M:3 D:1 ??:2")
2. Split into individual change types
3. Create a styled Span for each type with its color
4. Join the spans to create a colorized Line
5. Render in the table cell instead of plain text

This will make it much easier to quickly scan and identify what types of changes exist in each repository at a glance.

comments.text: Implemented colorized change summary rendering in UI table; errors remain red.

title: Implement CLI update mode per CLI.md
description:
Implement the CLI update mode described in CLI.md.

Scope:
- Mode selection: CLI mode when --pull/--push present; TUI otherwise.
- CLI options: --pull, --push, --repo <name>, --dry-run, --dirty <skip|allow|stash>.
- Defaults: if no --pull/--push in CLI mode, run pull then push.
- Target selection: match top-level folder name; error if not found; only one target.
- Operation order: pull then push.
- Dirty handling: skip/allow/stash (stash includes untracked, pop after; conflict => fail and leave stash).
- Failure handling: continue on other repos; summary; non-zero exit if any skipped/failed.
- Dry run: list repos and commands without executing.
- Output: one line per repo with OK/SKIP/FAIL and reason.
- Shared logic: CLI and TUI use same update runner (filtering, dirty handling, remote validation, execution, summary).

Notes:
- Keep behavior local-first; no telemetry or network beyond git.
acceptance_criteria:
- CLI mode triggered by update flags and respects PATH root.
- CLI options and defaults match CLI.md behavior.
- Dirty handling works for skip/allow/stash with correct failure semantics.
- Summary counts and exit codes are correct for mixed results.
- TUI update actions reuse shared runner.
